subject: Re: [junit] Class Not Found Error from a Command Line
msgSnippet: This information has changed with Java 1.6.  Now one can use a * and a directory of jars. From -
messageBody:
This information has changed with Java 1.6. Now one can use a * and a
directory of jars.

From - http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/tools/windows/classpath.html

Understanding class path wildcards
- Class path entries can contain the basename wildcard character *,
which is considered equivalent to specifying a list of all the files
in the directory with the extension .jar or .JAR. For example, the
class path entry foo/* specifies all JAR files in the directory named
foo. A classpath entry consisting simply of * expands to a list of all
the jar files in the current directory.

So a jar folder name is available in 1.6 when the * is used.

But this is new in 1.6 so a common oversight.

On Tue, Aug 18, 2009 at 5:11 PM, Vitaliy Berdinskikh<skipper13@...> wrote:
> В Tue, 18 Aug 2009 21:35:28 -0000
> "Jeff Sexton" <elgintime@...> пишет:
>
>> This is a common question, but just the same I can't see the trouble.
>>
>> On Windows with junit 4.1, I create a .bat file like so:
>>
>> set JARS=.\bin
>> set JARS=%JARS%;..\somedir\lib\junit.jar
> not ".\bin" but ".\bin\somejar1.jar;.\bin\somejar2.jar..."
>
> classpath contains class folder name and jar names. Not jar folder name.
>
> --
> Sincerely yours,
> Vitaliy Berdinskikh (Виталий Бердинских)
